data.title: Historical gardening event of the week: 21 January 1868
data.text:
GERMAN chemist Felix Hoffmann was born on this day. He was a researcher for Bayer (still a garden chemicals producer today) when his father developed chronic rheumatism. Keen to find a better pain reliever than salicylic acid (derived from salix, or willow) which tasted awful and caused stomach upsets, Felix conducted a number of experiments. He took spiraea (a close relation to the willow), and mixed together some of the acidic derivatives from the two plants. Testing showed that one of the compounds was a safe and effective drug for pain relief, lowering fever, and as an anti-inflammatory.
